snippet: The defendants had challenged the prison’s commander over a decision that would prohibit them from wearing camouflage in court.
abstract: Federal appeals court throws out terrorism conviction of Salim Hamdan, high-profile former detainee at Guantanamo Bay who had been Osama bin Laden's driver, ruling that charge against him--providing material support for terrorism--was not a recognized international war crime at the time of his actions; decision delivers setback to military commissions, reducing the chance that many other detainees at Guantanamo will receive trials.

byline.contributor: John H. Cushman Jr. contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: The defendants had challenged the prison’s commander over a decision that would prohibit them from wearing camouflage in court.

headline.seo: Bin Laden Driver’s Terror Conviction Is Reversed
headline.main: In Setback for Military Tribunals, Bin Laden Driver’s Conviction Is Reversed
headline.print_headline: In Setback for Military Tribunals, Bin Laden Driver’s Conviction Is Reversed

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
